body:
Weird: the error message appears only if the 2 lines for the namespaces are followed by this line (or perhaps another namespace):
`xmlns:p="http://primefaces.org/ui"`
Probably related to #4976

hi @akronenw, thanks for working on this!

> I refactored some code, mostly related to the files I touched anyway, hopefully not too much.

We usually try to avoid having cleanup and a bugfix in the same commit since it obfuscates the history esp when git blame is used. Would have been great if it would be kept separate here too - it makes review also easier.
@tbw777 also, can you please update the commit message to the PR title, so that it is less vague.

> Think we might have a little bit of work to do! smile I only searched for `javac.target`, so stupidly missed how many more modules just set `javac.source`! roll_eyes

the reason for that is because the custom javac ant task is mapping the properties in a non-standard way:
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/master/nbbuild/antsrc/org/netbeans/nbbuild/CustomJavac.java#L68-L100

but we are getting there. The good thing is that all values are now basically the same.


i saw this in the log `The Java platform version 8 or higher was requested but only 1.8 is running.` This indicates that i clearly overlooked some usages of the target property. Because this sounds like a module system warning so the number must have made it into the manifest. https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/410710ec8669a6134b508d28136627e39cab8d27/platform/autoupdate.services/src/org/netbeans/modules/autoupdate/services/DependencyChecker.java#L116

I did set source/target to 1.8 for the current test run.

going to try to get the default release property in too so that we can use it for all the other javac calls, e.g
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/3278/commits/bf8c26d91ea20cb7bf29b4510938f572f2202034

> > Think we might have a little bit of work to do! smile I only searched for `javac.target`, so stupidly missed how many more modules just set `javac.source`! roll_eyes
> 
> the reason for that is because the custom javac ant task is mapping the properties in a non-standard way: https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/master/nbbuild/antsrc/org/netbeans/nbbuild/CustomJavac.java#L68-L100

That is a n artifact of the NetBeans build itself, so the task is not set in stone and could be changed.

Yeah, it's ugly. It's been a while since I worked on this, but I seem to remember trying various approaches, including subclassing BasicTableUI, and concluding the stack trace approach was the lowest-risk way to fix it.

I hadn't seen the StackWalker API before; does it have advantages over Exception.getStackTrace?

Do you have statistical analysis, that with these changes the IDE performs any better? And if yes, how munch? Of course the overall performance of the IDE would be questionable "metric" alone.

-1 again.

Why are you doing these? What's your purpose with these kind of PRs?

@tbw777 I would not say this is a good PR, but one which actually could be merged. It creates relative small noise only 6 files affected. Though only 2 of them are actually in the IDE. Even those two are on some auxiliary execution path, used once or twice during one IDE execution.

The most value of this PR is an educative one, which is summarized succinctly by the new title.
Thank you.

Hello @mbien,
I understand. In the meantime I found out I solved this with too much effort, so I prepare a new PR and close this one. Sorry for the noise.
Alex
Was not able to reproduce. On Ubuntu 22.10, JDK 17.

@akronenw all good! Code cleanup in form of refactoring is perfectly fine btw, just keep it in a separate commit if possible and please avoid unnecessary formatting changes (e.g don't reformat whole files where you touched only a method).

Thanks a lot for fixing this issue!

Change looks sane.
Let's see result of CI.
Reproducible in NetBeans 17.

@mbien just to be sure - I automatically type CMD-SHIFT-F for for code formatting before saving. Every missing or abundant whitespace etc is then added/removed in the file. Did I get you right, that such formatting should be avoided?
Set was introduced to increase readability and for removeAll()/contains() calls. Reverted
@mbien Doesn't CI run tests of php.editor?

```
<record>
  <date>2023-02-08T15:36:01</date>
  <millis>1675841761744</millis>
  <sequence>1029</sequence>
  <level>700</level>
  <thread>155</thread>
  <message>UI_USER_CONFIGURATION</message>
  <key>UI_USER_CONFIGURATION</key>
  <catalog>org.netbeans.modules.uihandler.Bundle</catalog>
  <param>Windows 10, 10.0, amd64</param>
  <param>Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM, 16.0.2+7-67, Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment, 16.0.2+7-67</param>
  <param>Apache NetBeans IDE 12.5</param>
  <param></param>
  <param>java.util.ConcurrentModificationException at java.util.ArrayList.forEach</param>
  <param><Please provide a description of the problem or the steps to reproduce></param>
  <param>*********</param>
</record>
```
Wanted to dig a little bit more into it, but could not reproduce it.
I switched back to Arch Linux for now. So closing the issue.
@neilcsmith-net Can we close the issue?

> Set was introduced to increase readability and for removeAll()/contains() calls. Reverted

NB code didn't call `contains()` and taking a look at the `removeAll()` impl:
https://github.com/openjdk/jdk/blob/1fec6b5953b51dae4be640d6e4e4f79136b9348d/src/java.base/share/classes/java/util/AbstractSet.java#L166-L182

`contains()` is only called if the `toRemove` collection is larger than the set, however this can't happen as far as I see since `toRemove` is built by going through the collection first - so it is always smaller.

I do agree though that calling `set.removeAll(veryLargeList)` would potentially scale badly. But in the concrete cases here where we know how the list is build it should not cause this problem.

> @mbien Doesn't CI run tests of php.editor?

hi @junichi11, the label was added *after* the workflow request was built. Starting a fresh workflow will take new labels into account (restarting will not unfortunately).

This is the main reason we have the "secret" workaround of PR locking/unlocking which is used as trigger for a fresh workflow run (instead of restarting an old run which does not update its label information).

Usually committers can label PRs right away, so this problem doesn't exist there. It is only for contributions from non-committers which deliver a perfect PR which does not require any changes, like @troizet did with this PR :). (since changes will also trigger a fresh workflow run)

going to do this now and start a fresh workflow run here

I hope one day we will find a better solution for this
@mbien OK. Thanks!
@junichi11 thanks for checking that the correct tests run during review!
Somehow missed the broken test. Sorry. I'll keep looking into it.
I retried the same exclusions with NB 16. It seems to work. No more "running" processes.

This is a duplicate of #3962 Please have a look through there and try some of the suggestions.  We're still unclear what the cause of this issue is, so help in replicating, etc. is very useful.  Thanks!

> Usage must be replaced with alternatives like for example the Java 9 [Cleaner API](https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/17/docs/api/java.base/java/lang/ref/Cleaner.html) where needed.

We also already have a somewhat similar utilities API which might be of use for this? - https://bits.netbeans.org/17/javadoc/org-openide-util/org/openide/util/BaseUtilities.html#activeReferenceQueue--

`KeyEvent.getKeyModifiersText()` and `InputEvent.getModifiersExText()` on macOS have the problem that the order of the modifier symbols is different to the order used by macOS (left is Java, right is macOS:

![Untitled](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5604048/218698550-06ea3af3-6671-4b7e-8881-0b6530ad0332.png) ![Untitled 2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5604048/218698517-47a6408e-d7bd-4263-9ace-1895230116bd.png) 

That's why FlatLaf and Aqua L&F use own methods.
See: [FlatMenuItemRenderer.getMacOSModifiersExText()](https://github.com/JFormDesigner/FlatLaf/blob/546382e47170aa5b7132620b2cba32583d6011cc/flatlaf-core/src/main/java/com/formdev/flatlaf/ui/FlatMenuItemRenderer.java#L621-L644) and [AquaMenuPainter.getKeyModifiersUnicode()](https://github.com/openjdk/jdk/blob/92474f13f03afacc48541b0de17998998f70eb65/src/java.desktop/macosx/classes/com/apple/laf/AquaMenuPainter.java#L91-L126)

For right-to-left component orientation, Aqua L&F (and FlatLaf) reverses the order. E.g. Swing Aqua L&F:

![Untitled 7](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5604048/218707775-d20e0cf2-bcbf-4d56-8b6d-adc677461607.png)

BTW would suggest to replace deprecated `KeyEvent.getKeyModifiersText()` with `InputEvent.getModifiersExText()`.

Tried this out. I see the change in the main toolbar, but not in editor/view toolbars and other areas. I fear that this kind of code is used in many places. It is also surprising that text "Ctrl" or "Shift" (instead of symbols) is used in some places on macOS.

Editor toolbar:

![Untitled 3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5604048/218715607-4a27cd88-6cb3-4fb0-9b2d-fff95fd3fccb.png)

Options Keymap:

![Untitled 5](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5604048/218715717-efcf1dcd-e369-4c74-a03a-85f0eebc8f3e.png)

Editor macro shortcut:

![Untitled 6](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5604048/218715726-2591d501-d594-47d2-ac28-b03957ba8e99.png)

Editor popup:

![Untitled 4](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5604048/218716355-ac14b0de-9f70-4623-906f-1dd8958b1772.png)

Same situation in NB 17rc3
What makes Jakarta EE unusable for Jakarta Faces 4.0
Are we to understand that NB no longer supports JSF?
You are to understand that NB supports everything you provide support for at github.com/apache/netbeans.

Hi everybody,

I am a basic java developer and certainly unable to participate in the development of NB. 

I would like to continue to evolve and use Jakarta EE... and especially Jakarta Faces 4.0.

In no way, my message is a criticism, but a cry for help!

Have a nice day 

Louis

 

 

From: Geertjan Wielenga ***@***.***> 
Sent: mardi 14 fvrier 2023 12:48
To: apache/netbeans ***@***.***>
Cc: LouisCollet ***@***.***>; Comment ***@***.***>
Subject: Re: [apache/netbeans] no library found for namespace http://omnifaces.org/ui (Issue #4976)

 

You are to understand that NB supports everything you provide support for at github.com/apache/netbeans.


Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub <https://github.com/apache/netbeans/issues/4976#issuecomment-1429608191> , or unsubscribe <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ABVWDYJ6EFGCRZUIY7FJ5F3WXNWFFANCNFSM6AAAAAASCPKTMQ> .
You are receiving this because you commented.  <https://github.com/notifications/beacon/ABVWDYNN6BXHZ55AZI36TKDWXNWFFA5CNFSM6AAAAAASCPKTMSWGG33NNVSW45C7OR4XAZNMJFZXG5LFINXW23LFNZ2KUY3PNVWWK3TUL5UWJTSVGYLP6.gif> Message ID: ***@***.*** ***@***.***> >
Appreciated, thanks, @LouisCollet.

I did a substantial amount of cleanup in this area previously.

I count 149 remaining examples of this. Why is your code change much more than this?

Tried this. Works fine regarding "selection avoidance", but have the feeling that autoscrolling works not as good as before.

Have running two NB instances side-by-side (NB 16 from DMG and compiled master branch; on macOS).
Autoscrolling works pretty reliable in NB 16, but in the version with this PR, it often does not autoscroll.
Seems to depend on how fast I move the mouse out of the table...

Have tried a different solution:

- removed `mouseDragged` listener that invokes `scrollRectToVisible()`
- added following code from [JTable.changeSelection()](https://github.com/openjdk/jdk/blob/7dfe75cf553193faf709cff6b8b2505680d7cebc/src/java.desktop/share/classes/javax/swing/JTable.java#L2516-L2521) into "veto return" block in `ETable.changeSelection()`

I think this works a little bit better, but not as reliable as before. Don't know why  

Anyway, for compatibility, I would move autoscrolling to `ETable.changeSelection()` as done in `super.changeSelection()`.
This also avoids an additional listener and a possible side-effect of always scrolling while dragging.

Thereis a more difficult search patterns was found, for example

- miltilines:

```
List<String> test = condition ? Empty
: new ArrayList()
```

```
private static final Map<InstanceProperties, Boolean> PROPERTIES_TO_IS_RUNNING
        = Collections.synchronizedMap(new WeakHashMap());
```

```
FooCPP.roots2cps = Collections.unmodifiableMap(
        new HashMap() {
```

```
new ValidationResult( Collections.EMPTY_SET, 
        Collections.EMPTY_SET);
```

```
public static final NamedNodeMap EMPTY = 
        new NamedNodeMapImpl(new ArrayList(0));
```

- super:

`super(new HashMap());`

- synchronizedMap:

`Collections.synchronizedMap(new WeakHashMap());`

- Callable (one time as remember)
`TRUST_CHECK.submit(new Callable()`

- method params:
`setSelectedObjects(new HashSet());`

- String inline
`"Lookup.default<URLMapper>=" + Lookup.getDefault().lookup(new Lookup.Template(URLMapper.class))`

- Unmodifiable calls:
`Collections.unmodifiableSet(new HashSet(params)`

- imports path:
`super(new java.util.HashMap());`

- Internal type
`new ArrayListIterator(content); -> new ArrayListIterator<>(content);`

- iterator
`Collections.EMPTY_LIST.iterator() -> Collections.emptyListIterator();`

- previously skipped class fields such as:
`someMapVariableWithGenericType = new HashMap();`

And so on

> I hadn't seen the StackWalker API before; does it have advantages over Exception.getStackTrace?

It should be faster: https://www.sitepoint.com/deep-dive-into-java-9s-stack-walking-api/
But don't think that this would make a difference because it is not invoked very often here.

I'm using StackWalker in FlatLaf for similar purposes here: [StackUtilsImpl for Java 9+](https://github.com/JFormDesigner/FlatLaf/blob/main/flatlaf-core/src/main/java9/com/formdev/flatlaf/ui/StackUtilsImpl.java)
Here is [StackUtilsImpl for Java 8](https://github.com/JFormDesigner/FlatLaf/blob/main/flatlaf-core/src/main/java/com/formdev/flatlaf/ui/StackUtilsImpl.java) and base class [StackUtils](https://github.com/JFormDesigner/FlatLaf/blob/main/flatlaf-core/src/main/java/com/formdev/flatlaf/ui/StackUtils.java)
DefaultComboBoxModel will be refactored in the feature in separate PRs, therefore excluded

Update: just tried a DEV build without this PR, and autoscrolling is also not as reliable as in NB 16  

Selection-while-dragging also behaves slightly different (in Search results view):

- in NB 16, rows under mouse are selected immediately
- in DEV build, there is some delay and not all rows are selected

Both NB versions use same Java 11 VM.
Maybe this is a issue on my machine.
Or NB DEV build is started with different options than installed NB 16.
Or something else changed in NB 17...
BTW I've not checked out the commit of this PR. I'm on latest master and cherry picked this PR

Is there a DMG of NB 17rc available anywhere?

Here's what I would suggest and what I've previously done..

Reduce this check-in to 3 separate PRs. One for each of EMPTY_SET, EMPTY_LIST, and EMPTY_MAP.

It's just too large for me. But, if you do this, I will promptly review it.

Keep things simple. Really simple and you much more likely to get help.
awesome. We have a red master situation atm, have to resolve that first before starting the tests here. Going to be back later I promise :)

@DevCharly you'll have to use the zip at https://nightlies.apache.org/netbeans/candidate/netbeans/  There are unsigned installers for [other platforms](https://nightlies.apache.org/netbeans/candidate/installers/) but not a DMG.

This needs to be fixed in the used archetype.

see https://github.com/juneau001/jakartaee10-archetype/blob/main/src/main/resources/archetype-resources/src/main/resources/META-INF/persistence.xml

/cc @juneau001

please don't ever merge PRs which don't have tests run on them! This PR broke master. There is no need to hurry. 

This is a project wide cleanup which requires all tests to be run which is activated with the `ci:all-tests` label.

Hey @mbien, I reviewed this and the tests passed. So I approved it.

Did I make a mistake?
@BradWalker not all tests ran, see the message on the PR.

> please don't ever merge PRs which don't have tests run on them! This PR broke master. There is no need to hurry.
> 
> This is a project wide cleanup which requires all tests to be run which is activated with the `ci:all-tests` label.

As someone who has previously worked on things in this area, I spent the time to look at each file that was changed. So I'll accept the responsibility for what happened. It appeared to me that the tests were being "skipped" by design. Previously when I've looked at the test runs, the system always showed as "failed". So it was clearly my mistake. 

My apologies to everyone! I'll be more diligent next time!

the changes itself were fine, the problem was that some were in test data. Just don't be so quick with the merge button next time. It is perfectly fine to let a PR sit a few days - increases the probability that someone notices things like this, e.g missing label to run all tests.

> the changes itself were fine, the problem was that some were in test data. Just don't be so quick with the merge button next time. It is perfectly fine to let a PR sit a few days - increases the probability that someone notices things like this, e.g missing label to run all tests.

Agreed. 

I looked at each change. But, making a change in test code is definitely a danger. 

Another good reason to keep these type of PRs smaller in size.
all green, merging
we can do one PR, 3 commits. review and then squash before merge. This conserves resources.
simply force push into this PR. no need to start new ones.
@mbien , works for me..

> we can do one PR, 3 commits. review and then squash before merge.

Also, those seem fine as 3 commits to me without squashing - potentially worth keeping in history as is.

> just a question, is this email address correct? https://github.com/apache/netbeans/actions/runs/4175903071/jobs/7231902202#step:4:24 it looks a bit project specific :)

Yeah that's fine. Normally I create an e-mail address per purpose.

> Another good reason to keep these type of PRs smaller in size.

Fully agree. 

These huge PRs that change many files are prone to give problems. We should balance the benefits and the risks of these PRs.

And don't worry, @BradWalker ! This is something that could happen to anyone!
This is wrong. Next time please comment on the  mailing list before submitting PRs. Thanks.
@vieiro my first impression was, that this looks right. Can you explain why you think, that this is wrong?
@matthiasblaesing Because the removed part is still being used **in commented source code** in that the file. Removing it would make that commented code useless.
@vieiro thank you. I missed that.
@matthiasblaesing You're welcome!

> And don't worry, @BradWalker ! This is something that could happen to anyone!

@vieiro @BradWalker yes! This happens sometimes, so please don't worry about it. Its just that if you would have waited with the merge 1-2 days after review, I am certain someone would have noticed.

why?

because I for example try to look at https://github.com/apache/netbeans/actions on a daily basis to check if there is something to play whack-a-mole with, that is also how I noticed this in the first place. When someone syncs a new or old PR I would notice this too (since it appears on the all-knowing list) and probably check if its properly labeled. IMO the main lesson learned here should be to not rush PRs in, even if they seem trivial and were carefully reviewed.

This could have happened with a small PR too which only covers one module or less - it likely would have required some of the [[ci] labels](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/labels?q=%5Bci%5D) too. Java PRs need Java, PHP needs PHP otherwise the correct tests won't run etc etc.

also regarding large cleanup PRs in general:
in my book they are fine as long they remain reviewable (of course the PR itself should have a purpose too - I am not saying that every possible automated cleanup is worth the review time or to be integrated). It helps a lot to split large PRs into commits - if someone would only have the time to review one commit, thats fine - add a comment to tell the next reviewer.

We can't split everything into PRs otherwise every project wide cleanup would mean 18 PRs, one for each cluster - lets not do that.

@tbw777 I believe you misunderstood what @BradWalker said here: https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/5491#issuecomment-1429790958

please do the following:
 - remove the two commits which do the diamond changes since this PR is already large enough
 - split the empty collection commit into 3: one for Set, one for Map, one for List
 - force push into this PR

thanks!

Tried out NetBeans version 17-RC3. Unfortunately this issue is still present.
On a Java EE 8 project NetBeans does not recognize `xmlns:p="http://primefaces.org/ui"`, i.e., red all over the place. Same remark for a Quarkus project using JSF.

On a Jakarta EE 10 project NetBeans does not recognize `xmlns:h="jakarta.faces.html"`, but there `xmlns:p="http://primefaces.org/ui"` is OK.
Could somebody have a look at this before version 17? Such basic functionality should not get broken.

Incidentally, I did notice Gradle 8.0 is now out.

Sure. NB 16 did not support Jakarta EE 10.
Nothing here. Windows 11 [Version 10.0.22621.1265] , JDK 19.0.2.
Fixed

I think this reduces readbility and the JMH benchmarks are incorrect. `\w` is not `[A-Za-z0-9_]` and the same is true for the antipattern. There are also replacements in messages, which are equally questionable.

From me: -1

\w is [A-Za-z0-9_]
A proof: https://gist.github.com/tbw777/f62f96513157b47a150f0962e5f6f2e5

There is no underscore:

https://github.com/openjdk/jdk/blob/jdk-17+35/src/java.base/share/classes/java/util/regex/Pattern.java#L178-L179

and also not here:

https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/17/docs/api/java.base/java/util/regex/Pattern.html#predef

> \w  A word character: [a-zA-Z_0-9]
its not at the end (any position is applicable) in your examples
A sorry, overlooked, still, not more readable from my perspective.
Yee, but with \w cant be overlooked )

No, but I have to think what `\w` might mean. It might also change meaning depending on flags. It still leaves the question whether or not the messages should be changed and whether or not your JMH benchmarks have practical impact on real-life performance.

After doing a clean compile outside of netbeans, I realized I had an error in one of the relevant classes (apparently from a mistake caused by a previous refactor operation). I fixed that and tried the move again in netbeans. I still get an error, but the error is a little different:

Module Java Refactoring threw java.lang.IllegalStateException: java.lang.NullPointerException: Cannot read field "kind" because "tree.sym" is null. Please report a bug against Java Refactoring module and attach your var/log/messages.log.

I'm attaching the dumps. 

I should note that the class AbstractSpringTestCase that is evidently being choked on, is a test class that currently doesn't compile and that we are ignoring until we have time to do some rework around these classes. Perhaps I will need to configure netbeans to ignore them, however I will leave this bug report as I'm not sure that the move should fail in this way.
[Archive (1).tar.gz](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/files/10748865/Archive.1.tar.gz)

Ok, with the broken test classes removed so as not to be in the picture, I still run into this error with renames. Everything built with no errors before attempting the move, including the class mentioned in the log. Again attaching log and dump.

[Archive (2).tar.gz](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/files/10750570/Archive.2.tar.gz)

Another message that happens when rename refactoring fails:

"The original element being refactored is not available. It was deleted or significantly changed. Usages cannot be collected."

That is a lie.

>but I have to think what \w might mean.

Im disagree. Also long pattern havent single form: 24 options.

>It still leaves the question whether or not the messages should be changed and whether or not your JMH benchmarks have practical impact on real-life performance.

extended tests:
https://gist.github.com/tbw777/8ce56d2cc3a0216012362d18b7262eb2

Hello @asbachb, 
when I build my multi pom project, it also stops with the following exception:
`
java.lang.NullPointerException: Cannot invoke "org.openide.windows.FoldHandle.silentStartFold(boolean)" because "parentProject.foldHandle" is null
	at org.netbeans.modules.maven.execute.cmd.ExecutionEventObject$Tree.startFold(ExecutionEventObject.java:179)
	at org.netbeans.modules.maven.execute.CommandLineOutputHandler$Output.run(CommandLineOutputHandler.java:353)
	at org.openide.util.RequestProcessor$Task.run(RequestProcessor.java:1418)
	at org.netbeans.modules.openide.util.GlobalLookup.execute(GlobalLookup.java:45)
	at org.openide.util.lookup.Lookups.executeWith(Lookups.java:278)
[catch] at org.openide.util.RequestProcessor$Processor.run(RequestProcessor.java:2033)
`
Do you think that is also fixed by your PR?
Best
Alex
NetBeans 12.6 is unsupported, and it did not support JDK 18.  Please try with a NetBeans 16 or 17~rc3.

@akronenw base on your stack trace I don't think so. I could give it a try if you prepare a test project. Alternatively you could build my branch and test it your self. You just need `java 11`+ and `apache ant`.

I slightly agree with @matthiasblaesing 

If you don't know regex, you might still understand whats `[A-Za-z0-9_]` with `\w` you most likely need to look up which characters are included exactly.

@tbw777 if you run the same test per pattern twice is the output of both runs most likely equal?

e.g.

```
Regexps.testMatchLong         [A-Z_0-9a-z]  100000  thrpt       45397874,174          ops/s
Regexps.testMatchLong         [A-Z_0-9a-z]  100000  thrpt       45397874,174          ops/s
```

have you disabled jit for the benchmarks?

1) It's unclear which glassfish version you're using.
2) Afaik NetBeans is not supported to run on Java 8 anymore. Please try Java 11 or Java 17 as runtime for NetBeans. (see https://netbeans.apache.org/download/nb16/index.html)

@errael thanks for the review (and everyone else), I looked a second time through it and I believe it is good now. This one was time consuming - lets hope it was worth the effort.

all tests green again -> lets get this in

> NetBeans 12.6 is unsupported, and it did not support JDK 18. Please try with a NetBeans 16 or 17~rc3.
